docs.lead_paragraph: Connecticut will receive stock valued at nearly $81 million after the conversion of its health insurer, Anthem Blue Cross/ Blue Shield, to a publicly traded company. Gov. John G. Rowland announced yesterday that the state would receive about 1.7 million shares of stock. The state legislature and the governor are attempting to close a $100 million deficit. But it was not immediately clear whether or how much the stock would help with the deficit. The shares will become available in January, but cannot be sold until June.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: $81 Million Stock Windfall

docs.lead_paragraph: The 50 most-advertised prescription medicines contributed significantly last year to the increase in the nation's spending on drugs, according to a study. The report was prepared by the National Institute for Health Care Management, a nonprofit research foundation that was founded by the Blue Cross Blue Shield health insurance plans.

headline.main: Increased Spending on Drugs Is Linked to More Advertising

docs.abstract: Study by National Institute for Health Care Management, nonprofit research foundation that was founded by Blue Cross and Blue Shield health insurance plans, shows 50 most-advertised prescription medicines contributed significantly last year to increase in nation's spending on drugs; finds increases in sales of 50 drugs that were most heavily advertised to consumers accounted for almost half $20.8 billion increase in drug spending; says remainder of spending increase came from 9,850 prescription medicines that companies did not advertise or advertised very little; attributes spending increase to boost in number of prescriptions for 50 drugs, and not from rise in their price; only US and New Zealand permit advertising of prescription medicines to consumers; Food and Drug Administration is reviewing whether it should change rules it enacted in 1997 that made it easier for pharmaceutical companies to advertise their products on television; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WellPoint Health Networks Inc., the parent of Blue Cross of California, agreed to acquire CareFirst BlueCross BlueShield for $1.3 billion in cash and stock to add 3.1 million customers in Maryland, Delaware, Washington and Northern Virginia. WellPoint will pay $450 million in cash and $850 million in stock, a spokesman said. CareFirst, a nonprofit company, needs approval from regulators to convert to a for-profit company before the purchase can be completed. CareFirst had revenue of $3.1 billion in the nine months ended Sept. 30.

headline.main: WELLPOINT TO PURCHASE CAREFIRST IN $1.3 BILLION DEAL

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Genetic Testing of Women Aids in Cancer Fight'' (news article, Nov. 14) demonstrates the importance of passing federal legislation that prohibits discrimination based on genetic information. Under current federal law, individuals who take genetic tests to better care for their health may as a result be denied the insurance coverage they need. The findings that certain mutations of the BRCA1 and BRCA2 breast cancer genes have particularly high frequencies in Ashkenazi Jewish women bring the fear of genetic discrimination into the Jewish community.
docs.abstract: Janice L Greenwald letter calls for federal legislation to bar discrimination based on genetic testing, particularly in breast cancer gene mutation that may affect Jewish women (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The events of Sept. 11 and the recent plane crash in Queens (news articles, Nov. 19) have shown the special role of psychiatry and related mental health professions in these difficult times. Media coverage of acute stress reactions and the importance of seeking psychological care has reduced the stigma of seeking help. Many of the mental health professionals responding to the disasters have been volunteers, so something will have to give as people are encouraged to treat their symptoms down the line. But the insurance companies want to pay less and less for such treatment.

docs.lead_paragraph: For five years, Philip Lanni, partly disabled by dyslexia and other neurological impairments, worked as a radio dispatcher for the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection. And from his early days, the rangers Mr. Lanni sent to their jobs made him a target of pranks and ridicule, according to a lawsuit he won against the department in 1999. The rangers highlighted his spelling mistakes in his log book, he said, and tried to blame him for errors that were not his fault. ''We become the scapegoat,'' he said.

headline.main: Employers Increasingly Face Disability-Based Bias Cases

docs.abstract: Federal courts and juries are starting to treat workplace harassment of the disabled just as seriously cases of sexual or racial harassment, but many companies are still slow to respond to challenge; employers prevailed in more than 93 percent of cases reaching trial court level from 1992 through mid-1998 and 84 percent of time on appeal, but several highly pulicized lawsuits have recently overcome the considerable obstacles facing plaintiffs; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. unemployment rate rose sharply in October, to 5.4 percent, the biggest jump in five years. In New York, which is suffering the effects of a terrorist attack in the midst of an economic downturn, some 80,000 jobs were lost in October, a stunning decline in a month that can usually be counted upon for job growth.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column says 'potentially tragic conseuqences' of 1996 welfare-reform law, which among other things imposes five year lifetime limit on welfare assistance to needy families, will be felt in current economic downturn as individuals and families struggle with effects of recession; says seldom in last half-century has US been so poorly prepared to help needy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LONG before the economy started to sink, before terrorists crashed planes into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, before Cipro became part of the popular trademark lexicon, American health care had major problems. Now there are new twists. In New York, hospitals are reeling from the financial losses incurred after the attacks. Many of them made purchases to care for patients who, sadly, never came out of the World Trade Center. Hospitals also lost revenue when many patients canceled elective surgeries and other procedures immediately after the attacks.
docs.abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer column on many ways in which Sept 11 terrorist attacks have caused health care costs to rise across country and aggravated financial problems of hospitals in New York City, particularly those close to ground zero; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Alfredo Avelín is an eccentric country doctor known for his homespun philosophy, his poetry and a peculiar habit of playfully slapping the faces of visitors to his office. So perhaps it is not surprising that the other day he broke into a full-throated rendition of the tango classic ''It's a Kid's Dream'' when asked about President Fernando de la Rúa's plans to balance the federal budget to avert a national financial collapse.

headline.main: Argentina's Provinces Struggle to Stay Afloat

docs.lead_paragraph: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. EUGENE CLARK From the Terrace In life, Eugene Clark observed the three D's: dance, drama and divas. He started early: Roberta Flack was his music teacher in Washington, D.C., during the 1960's. He could sing like Jennifer Holliday in the musical ''Dreamgirls,'' he could emote like Norma Desmond in ''Sunset Boulevard'' and he danced ''like Tina Turner,'' said Larry Courtney, Mr. Clark's partner for the last 13 years. ''And he had legs almost as good.''

headline.main: Routines And Plans, And Friends And Family
